title: North Cave Wetlands Walking Route

images.title: Ian Lavender / North Cave Wetlands
images.caption: North Cave Wetlands, North Cave, East Riding of Yorkshire, England. A wildlife centre created from old gravel workings. Avocets are breeding here.

images.title: South Hide at North Cave Wetlands by peter robinson, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: South Hide at North Cave Wetlands

images.caption: Turret Hide at North Cave Wetlands

images.title: bernard bradley / Turret Hide from the south
images.caption: Turret Hide from the south. The high ground to the right and far distance are the Yorkshire Wolds

images.title: Africa Gomez / A view of North Cave Wetlands
images.caption: The reserve offers plenty of wetland habitats, over 200 sp. of birds and plenty of butterflies and dragonflies. It wade made making use of the workings of a sand and gravel quarry and first opened in 2004.

images.title: Far Lake at North Cave Wetlands by peter robinson, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Far Lake at the western side of the site.

images.title: bernard bradley / North Cave Wetlands Nature Reserve
images.caption: Grassy track around nature reserve. Shot taken in the north west corner of the reserve looking in an easterly direction.

images.title: bernard bradley / Information
images.caption: Information board at the site. This details the flora and fauna you can see. Pictures of a variety of birds and butterflies are visibile here.

description: This walk visits the North Cave Wetlands nature reserve in North Cave, East Riding of Yorkshire. The reserve is located just to the north west of the village with parking available at the site. You can then pick up a circular footpath taking you around the reserve's pretty lakes. It's an easy trail with grassy and surfaced section. There's lots of birdlife to look out for with a number of hides dotted around the site. Highlights include avocets and common terns, Sedge warbler, Snipe and lots of waders on the water. To continue your walking in the area head a couple of miles north to visit North Cliffe Woods near Market Weighton. The bluebell woods are also a nature reserve with deer to look out for from the shady paths.
